case_name: R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1964 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 95 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated April 14, 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 23 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 14, 1961 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 23 of 1958.

facts.text: Hakam Mal Tani Mal, a Hindu undivided family, was assessed to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918, in respect of income from business including timber at Abdullapur.

anchor.surface_text: Hakam Mal Tani Mal a Hindu undivided family was assessed to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918, in respect of income from business, inter alia, in timber at Abdullapur.

facts.text: In 1934, there was a partition of the Hindu undivided family Hakam Mal Tani Mal, and five members entered into a partnership named Ms Hakam Mal Tani Mal to carry on the business.

anchor.surface_text: In 1934 there was a partition of the Hindu undivided family, and five members of that family entered into a partnership to carry on in the name of M s Hakam Mal Tani Mal the business which was originally carried on by the undivided family.

facts.text: Accounts of the firm Hakam Mal Tani Mal were settled till March 31, 1939, and the firm was dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: Accounts of this firm were settled till March 31, 1939, and the firm was dissolved.

facts.text: Timber business of the firm Hakam Mal Tani Mal was taken over by two partners Gajjan Mal and Jodha Mal, who entered into a partnership named R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala (assessee).

anchor.surface_text: The timber business of the firm was taken over by two partners of the firm-Gajjan Mal and Jodha Mal, who entered into an agreement of partnership to carry on the business in the name of R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala-hereinafter called assessee.

facts.text: Instrument of partnership for assessee was executed on June 29, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: An instrument of partnership recording the terms of the partnership and reciting the dissolution of the earlier partnership was executed on June 29, 1939.

facts.text: The assessee firm R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala was dissolved in March 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was dissolved in March 1943.

facts.text: In assessment proceedings for 1943-44, the assessee contended it was entitled to relief under s. 25(3) or s. 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In assessment proceedings for 1943-44 the assessee contended that the firm Messrs Hakam Mal Tani Mal was dissolved on March 31, 1939, before the Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939 had come into force and the first succession to the business after April 1, 1939 was in March 1943...

facts.text: Income-tax Officer completed assessment without giving relief under s. 25(3) or 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer completed the assessment without giving to the assessee the benefit of sub-ss. (3) or (4) of s. 25 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order, holding succession to Hakam Mal Tani Mal took place on April 1, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order holding that succession to the family firm Messrs. Hakam Mal Tani Mal took place on April 1, 1939, and that firm alone was entitled to relief under s. 25(4)...

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal agreed with Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal agreed with the view of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court of Punjab directed Tribunal under s. 66(2) to draw up statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter as directed by the High Court of Punjab under s. 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the Tribunal drew up a statement of the case...

facts.text: Punjab High Court held assessee entitled to benefit of s. 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the assessee was carrying on business when Act 7 of 1939 was brought into operation and was on that account entitled to the benefit of s. 25(4) of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court preferred with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: There is no dispute that HUF Hakam Mal Tani Mal was taxed under 1918 Act and Ms Hakam Mal Tani Mal succeeded to business in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: Provided There is no dispute that the Hindu undivided family of Hakam Mal Tani Mal was taxed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918, in respect of the, timber business and Messrs. Hakam Mal, Tani Mal succeeded to that business in 1934.

facts.text: Accounts of Hakam Mal Tani Mal settled on March 31, 1939, timber business taken over by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Accounts of Messrs. Hakam Mal Tani Mal were settled on March 31, 1939, and the business in timber which was carried on by that firm was taken over by the assessee.

facts.text: Departmental authorities held assessee not carrying on business at commencement of Act 7 of 1939, succeeded on April 1, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The departmental authorities held that the assessee was at the commencement of the Indian Incometax Amendment Act 7 of 1939 not carrying on business, and that it succeeded to the business on April 1, 1943.

facts.text: Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939 brought into force on April 1, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939 was brought into force on April 1, 1939.

facts.text: Assessee contends it was carrying on business at commencement of Act 7 of 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee contends, and the contention has found favour with the High Court, that the assessee was carrying on business at the commencement of the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939.

facts.text: Partnership instrument executed by R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala and Gajjan Mal Kuthiala recites settlement of accounts upto March 31, 1939, partners separate from April 1, 1939, new partnership from April 1, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: We, R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala son of Lala Gopi Mal Sahib Sud of the one part and Gajjan Mal Kuthiala son of Lala Hakam Mal Sahib Sud Kuthiala of the other part... all the partners have become separate from the 1st of April, 1939, and the business... has fallen to our share... constituted a separate partnership... from the 1st of April, 1939.

facts.text: Court holds business of Hakam Mal Tani Mal continued till midnight of March 31, 1939, assessee commenced immediately thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of other evidence, it may be held that the business of Messrs. Hakam Mal Tani Mal continued till the midnight of March 31, 1939, and immediately thereafter the business of the assessee commenced.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds assessee was carrying on business at commencement of Act 7 of 1939 and entitled to s. 25(4) relief on dissolution in March 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our judgment, right in holding that the assessee was entitled on the dissolution of that firm in March 1943 to the benefit of s. 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Act 7 of 1939 deemed to come into operation immediately on expiration of March 31, 1939 per s.5(3) General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939 was brought into force on April 1, 1939. Section 5(3) of the General Clauses Act 10 of 1897 provides that unless the contrary is expressed, a Central Act or Regulation shall be construed as coming into operation immediately on the expiration of the day preceding its commencement.
entitled to relief under S. 25 3 , or in the alternative under s. 25 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

under s. 25 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Income-tax Officer completed the assessment without giving to the assessee the benefit of sub-ss.  3  or  4  of s. 25 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order holding that succession to the family firm Messrs. Hakam Mal Tani Mal took place on April 1, 1939, and that firm alone was entitled to relief under s. 25 4  and to the second succession which took place on April 1, 1943, after Act 7 of 1939 was brought into force relief under s. 25 4  was not admissible. Sub-section  4  was inserted in s. 25 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax Amendment Act 7 of 1939. It provides Where the person who was at the commencement of the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1939 (VII of 1939), carrying on any business, profession or vocation on which tax was at any time charged under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918, is succeeded in such capacity by another person, the change not being merely a change in the constitution of a partnership, no tax shall be payable by the first mentioned person in respect of the income, profits and gains of the period between the end of the previous year and the date of such succession, and such person may further claim that the income, profits and gains of the previous year shall be deemed to have been the income, profits and gains of the said period.

issues.text: Whether in the facts and the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal is correct in law in holding that the assessee firm R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala, Abdullapur Depot, Simla was not entitled to the benefit provided in Section 25(3) or 25(4) of the Income-tax Act, in relation to the assessment in question?

anchor.surface_text: tion of law for the opinion of the High Court Whether in the facts and the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal is companyrect in law in holding that the assessee firm  R. B. Jodha Mal Kuthiala, Abdullapur Depot, Simla  was number entitled to the benefit provided in Section 25  3  or 25  4  of the Income-tax Act, in relation to the assessment in question ?

issues.text: Whether the assessee was carrying on business at the commencement of the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1939 (7 of 1939)?

anchor.surface_text: The departmental authorities held that the assessee was at the companymencement of the Indian Incometax  Amendment  Act 7 of 1939 number carrying on business, and that it succeeded to the business on April 1, 1943. The High Court disagreed with that view and opined that the assessee was at the companymencement of Act 7 of 1939 carrying on business, and companyrectness of that opinion is challenged in this appeal.

issues.text: What is the true interpretation of the partnership deed executed on June 29, 1939, regarding the date of dissolution of the previous firm and commencement of business by the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companytends, and the companytention has found favour with the High Court, that the assessee was carrying on business at the companymencement of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act 7 of 1939. In support of the plea of the assessee reliance was placed only upon the instrument of partnership which was executed on June 29, 1939. The question in dispute must, therefore, be determined on a true interpretation of the terms of the instrument of partnership.
